questions.text: A 65-year-old man suffered from a stroke 2 days ago. He now presents with involuntary, violent, and flinging movements of the limbs on one side. What is the likely site of lesion in this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Subthalamic nuclei

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Most probable diagnosis as per the clinical history is hemiballismus which is caused by a lesion in subthalamic nuclei.
  • • Hemiballismus is a disorder characterized by violent involuntary abnormal movements on one side of the body involving mostly the arm. While walking, the arm swings widely. These movements are called the flinging movements. These movements are due to the release phenomenon because of the absence of inhibitory influence on movements. Hemiballismus occurs due to degeneration of subthalamic nucleus of Luys.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Globus pallidus : Incorrect for hemiballismus. Lesions here typically result in different forms of dyskinesia, such as parkinsonism or dystonia, but not hemiballismus.
  • • Option B. Globus pallidus
  • • Option C. Putamen : Also incorrect for this symptom. While putamen lesions are involved in many movement disorders, like Huntington's disease and some forms of Parkinson's disease, they do not typically cause hemiballismus.
  • • Option C. Putamen
  • • Option D. Caudate nucleus : Incorrect. Lesions in the caudate nucleus are more often associated with Huntington's disease, which leads to chorea—rapid, jerky movements—not the large-amplitude flinging movements seen in hemiballismus.
  • • Option D. Caudate nucleus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient presenting with unilateral flinging, violent limb movements following a stroke, the subthalamic nuclei should be considered as the primary site of lesion. This knowledge is crucial for accurate diagnosis and guiding treatment decisions, such as the use of neuroleptics or other interventions to control these disruptive movements.

questions.text: Night blindness history, corneal drying and patient has Bitot’s spots. Which of the following is found in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Phrynoderma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Symptoms of night blindness, corneal drying, and Bitot's spots, are indications of vitamin A deficiency. Phrynoderma, which is characterized by goosebump-like skin changes, is a manifestation of severe vitamin A deficiency and is the most relevant option in this context.
  • ➤ Ref -Dinesh Puri 3 rd e/pg. 393,
  • ➤ Ref -Dinesh Puri 3 rd e/pg. 393,

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman came to the OPD with a diagnosis of advanced cervical cancer. She has a 14-year-old daughter. What advice would you give for her daughter? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Advise HPV vaccine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The HPV vaccine is essential for preventing cervical cancer and should be administered to girls aged 9 to 14 years, ideally before the onset of sexual activity.

questions.text: In fetal circulation, which vessel carries deoxygenated blood back to the placenta? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Umbilical artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In fetal circulation, the umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta.

questions.text: What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Becker's naevus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Becker's naevus is a patchy, hyperpigmented lesion that often develops during adolescence and may include hypertrichosi s, distinguishing it from congenital conditions such as Mongolian spots, Naevus of Ito, and congenital melanocytic naevi.
  • ➤ Becker's naevus
  • ➤ patchy, hyperpigmented
  • ➤ adolescence
  • ➤ hypertrichosi
  • ➤ congenital

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presented to the casualty with confusion, ataxia, and painful eye movements. What could be the vitamin deficiency seen in this patient?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vitamin B deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wernicke encephalopathy – An acute, reversible but life-threatening condition. Clinical Vignette include Confusion, Ophthalmoplegia, Nystagmus, Ataxia.

questions.text: The floods had an impact on Kerala's Pathanamthitta district, leading the government to provide doxycycline tablets for prophylaxis. What other chemical is set to be distributed in conjunction with this? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Zinc phosphide

Explanation:

  • • Explanation -
  • • The government distributed doxycycline tablets for prophylaxis following floods in Kerala to prevent the spread of diseases such as leptospirosis, acute diarrheal diseases, and dengue.
  • • Leptospirosis, which is caused by contaminated water with rodent urine, can be prevented by chemoprophylaxis with Doxycycline, using rubber shoes and gloves, anti-rodent measures, and establishing a proper drainage system. Zinc phosphide is used for chemical control of rodents due to its good safety record, low cost and high effectiveness Chlorine tablets and bleaching powder are used to disinfect household water supply. Insecticides and larvicides like abate are used for indoor residual sprays for drinking water. General hygiene and sanitary measures must also be followed to control the spread of diseases during floods.
  • • Leptospirosis, which is caused by contaminated water with rodent urine, can be prevented by chemoprophylaxis with Doxycycline, using rubber shoes and gloves, anti-rodent measures, and establishing a proper drainage system.
  • • Zinc phosphide is used for chemical control of rodents due to its good safety record, low cost and high effectiveness
  • • Zinc phosphide
  • • Chlorine tablets and bleaching powder are used to disinfect household water supply. Insecticides and larvicides like abate are used for indoor residual sprays for drinking water.
  • • Chlorine tablets and bleaching powder
  • • General hygiene and sanitary measures must also be followed to control the spread of diseases during floods.

questions.explanation:
Ans.

questions.text: A child presented with hydrocephalus, intracranial calcification, and bilateral chorioretinitis. What can be the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A middle-aged woman who presented with tremors, palpitations, weight loss, and menstrual irregularities is diagnosed with Graves' disease. Which of the following statements would be correct with respect to her thyroid function test? (NEET PG 2018)

options.label: D
options.text: Radioactive iodine Uptake (RAIU) at 24 hours below normal

questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Low TSH levels

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Graves' disease, low TSH levels are a key diagnostic marker reflecting the increased production and release of thyroid hormones T3 and T4, which exert negative feedback on the pituitary gland to reduce TSH secretion.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison 21/Hyperthyroidism/Grave’s disease/Chap 384

questions.text: A comparison is made between the variability present in one dataset and that in another dataset by: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Coefficient of variation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Coefficient of Variation (CV) is the appropriate measure for comparing the relative variability of different datasets because it standardizes the measure of dispersion relative to the mean, allowing for meaningful comparisons across different datasets.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding an allosteric modifier? (NEET PG 2018)

options.label: B
options.text: Causes the enzyme to work faster only

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Participates in feedback regulation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Allosteric Regulation
  • ➤ Allosteric Regulation
  • ➤ Allosteric enzyme has one catalytic site where the substrate binds and another separate allosteric site where the modifier binds (allo = other). Allosteric and substrate binding sites may or may not be physically adjacent. The binding of the regulatory molecule can either enhance the activity of the enzyme ( allosteric activation ), or inhibit the activity of the enzyme ( allosteric inhibition ). In the former case, the regulatory molecule is known as the positive modifier and in the latter case as the negative modifier . The binding of substrate to one of the subunits of the enzyme may enhance substrate binding by other subunits. This effect is said to be positive cooperativity . If the binding of substrate to one of the subunits decreases the avidity of substrate binding by other sites, the effect is called negative cooperativity. In feedback mechanism, one of the intermediates or products will go back and bind to the allosteric site of one of the enzymes involved in the series of reactions, thereby either inhibiting or activating the enzyme.
  • ➤ Allosteric enzyme has one catalytic site where the substrate binds and another separate allosteric site where the modifier binds (allo = other).
  • ➤ one catalytic site
  • ➤ separate allosteric site
  • ➤ Allosteric and substrate binding sites may or may not be physically adjacent.
  • ➤ The binding of the regulatory molecule can either enhance the activity of the enzyme ( allosteric activation ), or inhibit the activity of the enzyme ( allosteric inhibition ).
  • ➤ allosteric activation
  • ➤ allosteric inhibition
  • ➤ In the former case, the regulatory molecule is known as the positive modifier and in the latter case as the negative modifier .
  • ➤ positive modifier
  • ➤ negative modifier
  • ➤ The binding of substrate to one of the subunits of the enzyme may enhance substrate binding by other subunits. This effect is said to be positive cooperativity . If the binding of substrate to one of the subunits decreases the avidity of substrate binding by other sites, the effect is called negative cooperativity.
  • ➤ positive cooperativity
  • ➤ negative cooperativity.
  • ➤ In feedback mechanism, one of the intermediates or products will go back and bind to the allosteric site of one of the enzymes involved in the series of reactions, thereby either inhibiting or activating the enzyme.

questions.text: A male child presented with arthralgia and abdominal pain. On examination, there was palpable purpura over the lower limbs. There is a past history of upper respiratory tract infection prior to the onset of presenting symptoms. Which of the following is the treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Glucocorticoids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary treatment for Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), particularly with significant gastrointestinal involvement or severe symptoms, is glucocorticoids such as prednisolone.

questions.text: Which of the following helps in bacterial adhesion? ( NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fimbriae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fimbriae are essential bacterial structures for adhesion, enabling bacteria to attach to host cells and surfaces, crucial for initiating infections and forming biofilms. This key role makes them important targets for strategies to prevent and treat bacterial infections.

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient presented with slowly progressive motor weakness, nuchal rigidity, and difficulty in swallowing and carrying out day-to-day activities. A provisional diagnosis of multiple sclerosis is suspected. Which of the following cells are affected in multiple sclerosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Oligodendrocytes

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Oligodendrocytes are affected in multiple sclerosis.
  • • In multiple sclerosis (MS), myelin-forming oligodendrocytes (OLGs) are the targets of inflammatory and immune attacks. OLG death by apoptosis or necrosis causes the cell loss seen in MS plaques, and leads to loss of conduction or delayed conduction in the demyelinated axons.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Microglia. are the primary immune cells of the central nervous system, similar to peripheral macrophages.
  • • Option A. Microglia.
  • • Option C. Astrocytes. also known collectively as astroglia, are characteristic star-shaped glial cells in the brain and spinal cord. They perform many functions, including biochemical control of endothelial cells that form the blood–brain barrier.
  • • Option C.
  • • Astrocytes.
  • • Option D. Ependymal cells. are ciliated-epithelial glial cells that develop from radial glia along the surface of the ventricles of the brain and the spinal canal. They play a critical role in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) homeostasis, brain metabolism, and the clearance of waste from the brain.
  • • Option D.
  • • Ependymal cells.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In multiple sclerosis, the primary pathological change occurs in oligodendrocytes, the cells responsible for myelinating neurons in the CNS. This leads to widespread neurological impairment due to the loss of myelin, affecting the efficiency of nerve signal transmission.

questions.text: A 33-year-old female patient comes with complaints of menorrhagia for the past 3 months. The duration and regularity of her menstrual cycles are normal. Non- hormonal management has been tried without success. What is the most appropriate next step? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hormonal therapy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Hormonal therapy is the next best management modality for menorrhagia when non-hormonal management has failed. This includes combined oral contraceptive pills or even progesterone-only devices like the LND-IUS. First-line management includes non-hormonal treatment like NSAIDs and Tranexamic acid.
  • • Hormonal therapy is the next best management modality for menorrhagia when non-hormonal management has failed. This includes combined oral contraceptive pills or even progesterone-only devices like the LND-IUS.
  • • First-line management includes non-hormonal treatment like NSAIDs and Tranexamic acid.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. Uterine artery embolization : Uterine artery embolization is a surgical option and is considered when other treatments fail.
  • • Option A. Uterine artery embolization
  • • Option B. Endometrial ablation : Endometrial ablation is also a surgical option and should be considered after hormonal therapy.
  • • Option B. Endometrial ablation
  • • Option D. Hysterectomy : Hysterectomy is the last resort and is used when all other management options fail or are contraindicated.
  • • Option D. Hysterectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Hormonal therapy, including combined oral contraceptive pills or progesterone-only devices like the LND-IUS, is the next best management step for menorrhagia when non-hormonal management has been ineffective.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 197, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 197, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6 th edition

questions.text: Which condition is characterized by facial palsy due to herpes infection involving the geniculate ganglion? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ramsay Hunt Syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Ramsay Hunt Syndrome is characterized by facial palsy due to herpes zoster infection (varicella-zoster virus) involving the geniculate ganglion of the facial nerve. It presents as a triad of facial nerve palsy, vesicular eruptions on the pinna and external auditory canal, and vestibulocochlear symptoms. The infection represents a reactivation of the herpes zoster virus that had remained dormant in the geniculate ganglion after previous chickenpox infection.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Heerfordt Syndrome : This is a rare manifestation of sarcoidosis characterized by the triad of uveitis, parotid gland enlargement, and facial nerve palsy. It is not related to herpes infection of the geniculate ganglion. The facial palsy in this condition is due to granulomatous infiltration of the facial nerve.
  • • Option A. Heerfordt Syndrome
  • • Option C. Bell's Palsy : While this is also a facial nerve paralysis, Bell's palsy is idiopathic in nature. Although some theories suggest that herpes simplex virus may be involved in some cases of Bell's palsy, it does not specifically involve vesicular eruptions or definitive evidence of geniculate ganglion involvement as seen in Ramsay Hunt Syndrome.
  • • Option C. Bell's Palsy
  • • Option D. Melkersson's Syndrome : This syndrome (also called Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome) is characterized by recurrent or persistent facial swelling, recurrent facial paralysis, and a fissured tongue (lingua plicata). It is not caused by herpes infection of the geniculate ganglion but is thought to be related to granulomatous disease.
  • • Option D. Melkersson's Syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ramsay Hunt Syndrome is specifically characterized by facial nerve palsy due to herpes zoster infection of the geniculate ganglion, presenting with the distinctive triad of facial paralysis, ear/mouth vesicles, and auditory/vestibular symptoms.

questions.text: All are true about patients with trigeminal neuralgia except: (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: B
options.text: Pain along V2 and V3 division of trigeminal nerve

options.label: D
options.text: No objective signs of sensory loss

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Deep seated pain

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trigeminal neuralgia is marked by sharp, superficial pain that may affect the V2 and V3 divisions of the trigeminal nerve. It is important to recognize that the pain is superficial and not deep-seated. This condition more commonly affects females and presents without objective sensory loss.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Trigeminal neuralgia

questions.text: Mr. Seth recently underwent surgery to remove a parathyroid gland due to hyperparathyroidism. The surgeon informed the patient that one or more of the parathyroid glands may be transferred to another location during the surgery to protect them or due to their location. The parathyroid is commonly transferred to? ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Brachioradialis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The most common site for the relocation of the parathyroid gland(s) is in the forearm muscle, specifically the nondominant side brachioradialis. Transplantation to this location provides several advantages:
  • • Accessibility : The forearm location is easily accessible for potential future surgical interventions if necessary. Monitoring : This location allows for straightforward monitoring of parathyroid function using simple clinical tests. Functionality : The transplanted gland(s) will continue to produce parathyroid hormone normally, aiding in the regulation of calcium levels in the body. Ease of Removal : If there is disease recurrence after surgery, the forearm location facilitates easy removal. Typically, a total of 12 to 14 pieces are transplanted in a type of heterotopic transplant.
  • • Accessibility : The forearm location is easily accessible for potential future surgical interventions if necessary.
  • • Accessibility
  • • Monitoring : This location allows for straightforward monitoring of parathyroid function using simple clinical tests.
  • • Monitoring
  • • Functionality : The transplanted gland(s) will continue to produce parathyroid hormone normally, aiding in the regulation of calcium levels in the body.
  • • Functionality
  • • Ease of Removal : If there is disease recurrence after surgery, the forearm location facilitates easy removal.
  • • Ease of Removal
  • • Typically, a total of 12 to 14 pieces are transplanted in a type of heterotopic transplant.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Triceps: Triceps is not a preferred site for parathyroid transplantation due to less accessibility and monitoring challenges compared to the brachioradialis.
  • • Option A. Triceps:
  • • Option B. Biceps: Biceps is also not commonly used for parathyroid transplantation because it does not offer the same ease of access and monitoring advantages as the brachioradialis.
  • • Option B. Biceps:
  • • Option C. Sartorius: Sartorius is not a preferred site for parathyroid transplantation. The forearm muscle (brachioradialis) is favored for its convenience and monitoring benefits.
  • • Option C. Sartorius:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The brachioradialis muscle in the forearm is the most common site for parathyroid gland relocation during surgery due to its ease of access, convenient monitoring, and straightforward removal if needed.

questions.text: Infection with Clonorchis sinensis is associated with an increased risk of? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cholangiocarcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Infection with Clonorchis sinensis is primarily associated with an increased risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma, emphasizing the importance of avoiding consumption of undercooked freshwater fish in endemic areas to prevent this parasitic infection.

questions.text: Nugent score is for diagnosis of? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Nugent score is used for the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis . It is a microbiological scoring system where the vaginal smear is analyzed for the number of lactobacilli and abnormal bacteria. The clinical scoring system for bacterial vaginosis is the Amsel's criteria , which includes the whiff test, clue cells, alkaline pH, and whitish discharge.
  • ➤ Nugent score
  • ➤ bacterial vaginosis
  • ➤ Amsel's criteria

questions.text: Painful arc syndrome is seen in:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Mid-abduction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Painful arc syndrome, a clinical manifestation of impingement syndrome, is observed during mid-range shoulder abduction, typically between 60° and 120°. This condition is often seen in individuals engaging in activities that involve repeated arm elevation, and management may include NSAIDs, corticosteroid injections, physical therapy, or, in refractory cases, surgical intervention to decompress the subacromial space.

questions.text: You are applying a vacuum to deliver a baby in a patient with prolonged 2nd stage. The point at which the vacuum is applied is: (NEET PG 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle

options.label: B
options.text: 6 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle

options.label: C
options.text: 4 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle

options.label: D
options.text: Midway between the anterior and posterior fontanelle

questions.correct_answer: A. 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The flexion point, located 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle, is the optimal site for applying a vacuum during delivery to achieve the necessary head flexion.

questions.text: Which statement is incorrect about the pathology shown?(NEET PG 2019)

options.label: D
options.text: Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice

questions.correct_answer: D. Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Giant Cell Tumor (GCT) of bone typically manifests as an eccentric lytic lesion in the epiphyseal region of long bones with distinct margins. The mainstay of treatment for GCT is surgical intervention, either through curettage or excision followed by bone grafting, rather than chemotherapy. This surgical approach helps ensure complete removal of the tumor and helps prevent recurrence.
